Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Low-Cost, Copper-Based Metallization Pastes for Solar Cell Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will study the feasibility of using abundant elements in metallization pastes for crystalline silicon solar cells. Currently, silver-based pastes dominate the market because they do not oxidize and can be processed at high temperatures. Unfortunately, these pastes contain a large fraction of silver (e.g. >50%), which is a precious metal that currently costs ~$1000/kg. During this feasibility study, PLANT PV will attempt to synthesize and fabricate low-cost thin films of composite metal particles made from abundant elements that can be used as a replacement for Ag-pastes. In order to achieve success, the films must be sufficiently conductive and strongly adhere to the silicon solar cell while not reducing the overall power conversion efficiency.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be a significant reduction in the overall cost of PV cell processing. Currently PV modules cost $0.70-0.80/W to produce with roughly $0.08/W cost coming from the silver based metallization pastes. The global silver paste market in the PV industry is >$1.8 bn/year. We believe that by switching to non-silver alternatives it is possible to provide significant cost reductions (e.g. >$0.05/W). Module cost reductions have primarily driven the significant growth in solar cell installations in the United States in the past five years. While PV is now cost competitive in several regions in the US, further solar module reductions to $0.50/W, with commensurate reductions in installation costs, would make solar power cost competitive with >1TW of power production in the US without subsidies. Finally, metallization pastes developed in this Phase I study may have applications in a wide range of products including displays and integrated circuits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PLANT PV is developing metallization pastes comprised of low-cost base metals to form rear tabbing lines on silicon (Si) photovoltaic cells (PV). Metal lines are formed on silicon solar cells by screen printing metallization pastes onto the silicon wafer and then firing in an oxygen rich environment. Commercially available rear tabbing metallization pastes (e.g. DuPont PV505, Heraeus SOL205S) are comprised of 60% wt silver, which represents >70% of the total paste price. The goal of PLANT PV is to develop rear tabbing metallization pastes that use 50% less silver loading and achieve comparable performance, reliability, and yield.

 

Silver-based metallization pastes are inherently expensive because of the amount of silver required and the commodity price of silver, which is close to $700/kg in 2014.  Silver based metallization pastes are the second largest materials cost of Si PV cells and it is estimated that the PV industry currently uses over 5% of all annual silver production.  It is projected that 10% of global silver production will be used for solar cells by 2015. Continued, large increases in PV cell production are unsustainable in the long-term given the high cost of silver. In addition, screen printing is widely used by PV cell manufacturers because of the low cost-of-ownership of the printers. It is thus highly desirable to develop metallization pastes that not only reduce silver usage but that are also compatible with existing screen printers.

 

It is very challenging to develop novel metallization pastes that do not use precious metals (e.g. Ag, Au, and Pt) due to the high temperature firing process performed in air during the formation of the metal electrodes on the solar cell. All low-cost base metal particles (e.g., Ni, Al, Cu) oxidize under these conditions resulting in embrittlement of the film, loss of bulk conductivity and lack of solderability to copper tabbing ribbons when making modules.

 

During the NSF Phase I project PLANT PV successfully developed a low-cost metal alloy coating on Ni particles that prevents Ni oxidation when the particles are rapidly fired in air. Furthermore, we demonstrated that after the firing process the metal alloy coated Ni particles remained both solderable and conductive. Finally, we demonstrated Ni-based metallization pastes that showed strong adhesion to silicon and that did not deleteriously affect the recombination dynamics in the silicon when compared against state-of-the-art Ag paste.

 

During Phase I, PLANT PV also performed extensive customer discovery through numerous meetings and site visits with potential customers (e.g. Hanwha SolarOne, SolarWorld, Suniva, and REC Cells). In addition, we met with companies throughout the value chain including competitors (e.g. DuPont), potential partners (e.g. PVMC, UCEP, D2 Solar) and businesses that have recently commercialized metallization pastes (e.g. PARC and Five Star). Through this discovery process we were able to clearly define our product and formulate scale-up and go-to-market strategies. Based on the discovery process, our “Gen I” product will be a rear tabbing paste that reduces the current silver loading in rear tabbing pastes by 50%. This will be achieved by replacing Ag particles with low-cost Ni particles coated with PLANT PV’s proprietary shell. This level of Ag reduction will result in >35% cost savings to the cell makers and allow them to use their existing equipment and processing methods. Every PV cell manufacturer that we engaged said they were willing to perform pilot scale testing of our Gen I paste.
